mentions.context: Volumetric maps were computed with VMD. PYMOL was used for figure preparation.
Heatmaps were prepared with R using the ComplexHeatmap package [79].
Trajectories were graphically analyzed with VMD [77] and PYMOL (DeLano Scientific LLC, San Franscisco, USA).
They were performed using the HPC resources of IDRIS, granted by GENCI (www.genci.fr).
We used the dual boost method as implemented in NAMD [75].
H-bonds were measured with the H-bond facility of VMD with cutoffs of 30˚and 3.5Å.
Trajectories were graphically analyzed with VMD [77] and PYMOL (DeLano Scientific LLC, San Franscisco, USA).

The model of the chimeric AT1c variant was prepared using MODELLER from the model of AT1h by substituting the sequence from residue 3.25 to 3.40 by the equivalent positions in AT2h [35]: AT1h: CKIASASVSFNLYASV AT2h: CKVFGSFLTLNMFASI Two models of inactive human AT2 were built using MODELLER from the active-like 5UNG AT2 structure [21] and from the inactive AT1h model.
Quantitative analyses were carried out with home-developed scripts, written in tcl, for use with the VMD software, and in R using functions from the Bio3D R package [78].
Quantitative analyses were carried out with home-developed scripts, written in tcl, for use with the VMD software, and in R using functions from the Bio3D R package [78].
A point mutation in this structure was reversed to the wild type sequence with MODELLER.
To obtain a non-redundant set of vertebrate receptors, we clustered the 318 sequences using the NRDB program [28], with a threshold of 90% sequence identity.
Quantitative analyses were carried out with home-developed scripts, written in tcl, for use with the VMD software, and in R using functions from the Bio3D R package [78].
All the snapshots of the sodium-bound receptor were superimposed on the initial model and saved as PDB files, using VMD.
Molecular dynamics simulations of the receptor models embedded into the hydrated POPC bilayer were carried out using NAMD 2.13 MD software [70] and the Charmm36 parameter set [71,72].
A Neighbour-Joining (NJ) phylogenetic tree of the aligned representative sequences of the clusters was built with the MEGA5 software [65] using 500 replicates for bootstrapping.
The PDB files for the sodiumfree receptor and for the sodium ion were obtained from the sodium-bound receptor PDB files with shell scripts.
Quantitative analyses were carried out with home-developed scripts, written in tcl, for use with the VMD software, and in R using functions from the Bio3D R package [78].

The inactive state of AT1h with bound sodium was modeled from the sodium-free 4YAY [17] and 4ZUD [18] structures of AT1 and from the sodium-bound structure of OPRD (4N6H) [36], using the homology modeling software MODELLER [67].

The over representation of highly similar mammalian sequences in this set (120 mammalian AT1 sequences out of 203, 68 mammalian AT2 sequences out of 115) prompted us to build a non-redundant (NR) set using the perl script NRDB.pl [28].

The model of the chimeric AT1c variant was prepared using MODELLER from the model of AT1h by substituting the sequence from residue 3.25 to 3.40 by the equivalent positions in AT2h [35]: AT1h: CKIASASVSFNLYASV AT2h: CKVFGSFLTLNMFASI Two models of inactive human AT2 were built using MODELLER from the active-like 5UNG AT2 structure [21] and from the inactive AT1h model.
